Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Om mani padme hum. Om mani padme hum.

Speaker: lhamo
Dialogue: Cow.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Yes.  A cow had died. One night, you stopped all your moving, and I said to your sister, "His time has come."

Speaker: lhamo
Dialogue: Me.  First break of day.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: At dawn, you were born. One eye was closed, and your sister opened it with her thumb.  We gave you the sweet drink.

Speaker: lhamo
Dialogue: I pooped.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: You did.  We washed you and wrapped you in sheepskin and took you to your father.  That day he father got better

Speaker: lhamo
Dialogue: I miss my brother.

Dialogue: I miss him too.

Dialogue: Sera Monastery?  From Lhasa?

Dialogue: Yes.  We have business here.

Dialogue: This is yours, you say. What else belongs to you?

Speaker: keustang rinpoche
Dialogue: Yes, those are yours.

Speaker: keustang rinpoche
Dialogue: With permission?

Speaker: keustang rinpoche
Dialogue: "Kundun"

Dialogue: He is the Presence.

Dialogue: My oldest boy is an incarnation.

Speaker: keustang rinpoche
Dialogue: So is your youngest.

Speaker: keustang rinpoche
Dialogue: I wish you long life.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I will be back in a few days.

Dialogue: How many?

Dialogue: Two.

Dialogue: This many?

Dialogue: Yes, yes.  Your brothers are here.

Dialogue: One more kiss.

Speaker: keustang rinpoche
Dialogue: This is Tibet. We are not under your authority.

Dialogue: I want one hundred thousand Chinese dollars, if you want the boy.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: But why?  Who is Lhamo? Who do they say he is?

Speaker: teacher
Dialogue: "May I be a bridge, a boat, a ship For all who wish to cross the water."

Dialogue: Can you recite?

Dialogue: You have all the room.

Dialogue: Don't be a baby, move over.

Dialogue: You move.

Dialogue: You!  You think you are so big!

Speaker: lhamo
Dialogue: Who am I?

Dialogue: We do not know.

Dialogue: Chenrezi, the Buddha of compassion. The Wish Fulfilling Jewel. The Fourteenth Dalai Lama.

Speaker: reting rinpoche
Dialogue: Long life.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Long life.

Dialogue: Long life.

Dialogue: Long life, Lhamo.

Dialogue: Kundun!  Kundun!

Dialogue: Centuries ago, a young boy was born.  His name was Gedundrub. The night of his birth, robbers came to his home and his family fled hiding the baby in a cattle pen. When they returned the next day, the baby was safe. They found him guarded by a pair of black crows.

Speaker: reting rinpoche
Dialogue: We name you Tenzin Gyatso.

Speaker: reting rinpoche
Dialogue: Your job is simple. You are to love all living things. Just love them.  Care for them. Have compassion for them.

Speaker: reting rinpoche
Dialogue: You will be the leader of the Tibetan people when you come of age.  Until that time, I will be your teacher, and as your Regent, I will rule in your name.

Speaker: reting rinpoche
Dialogue: He will see you now.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Fifth Dalai Lama.

Speaker: lord chambberlain
Dialogue: Seventh Dalai Lama.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Thirteenth Dalai Lama.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Fourteenth Dalai Lama.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: My name is Norbu, Holiness.  I will be good, you be bad.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I'm on a big mountain and hitting at the bad men. And after the game, we're going to trade.  You just stay over there, no, there!, Norbu, and I will shoot at you. I want your land.  I take it. I am stronger.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: I am braver.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I have more men.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Today you lose.  Tomorrow you may win.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Things change, Kundun.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Why is your beard so funny? Let me touch this.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Soft.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: "As long as all living draw breaths, there Buddha is."

Speaker: layman
Dialogue: I believe that the Regent is asking for too high a reward for his part in finding the Dalai Lama.  Too much money, too much land.

Speaker: layman
Dialogue: Our treasuries are empty.  Our army is depleted.  He would have us pull the hair from our noses.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: We note this.  Now, the Chinese.

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: The Allies wish to build a supply- road from India, crossing Tibet, as part of their war effort.  The road would lead directly to China.

Speaker: layman
Dialogue: We cannot allow it. Right now, we have a only a small Chinese mission in Lhasa, the first since the Thirteenth Dalai Lama threw them out in 1912. The road would increase the size of that mission. The Chinese would try to control our trade, as they did once before, control our contact with the outside world.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: the attendants
Dialogue: Ah, it is a telescope, Holiness. With this you can see a long way.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: And, is it mine?

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: These are all gifts sent to your predecessors.

Speaker: lobsang samten
Dialogue: Yes!  Then it is yours!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I need it.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: She carried a basket in her arms, a big, heavy basket, and the old monk cautiously approached. She opened her basket and showed what she had.  Heads.  Human heads. Only the heads.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Is that true or pretend?

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: It is a story, you decide.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Pretend.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: As you say.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: "I be an island for those who seek one, a lamp for light."

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: "May I be wishing jewel, a magic vase...

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I want to go down there.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: You can only go with attendants and a big ceremony.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I want to run down the street. I want to buy a toy.  Eat from the shops.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: You cannot.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I want to be a shepherd, taking those goats and cows out to the hillside.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: But you are not a shepherd, you are the Dalai Lama.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Maybe in the next life, the world will not need a Dalai Lama.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Little ones first, only little ones.

Speaker: lobsang samten
Dialogue: The Dalai Lama is not supposed to eat pork.  It is not good for your brain.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I am sorry, Lhamo.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: It is alright, Father.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Go away.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Not the way to talk to people.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Can I do anything I want?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: But, I am in charge.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Are you?  Of whom?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Can I save the sheep from going to the market?  So they don't die.

Speaker: lobsang
Dialogue: You could buy them.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Do I have money?

Speaker: lobsang
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Do you have money?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I do, now.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: And you have horses? You love horses.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I do, beautiful horses. Thank you, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Will you buy the sheep for me?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Where will you keep them?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Here.  We'll collect them.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: I will buy them for you.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Can I free the prisoners?

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Hmmm.

Speaker: lobsang
Dialogue: You can't do anything real until you are Dalai Lama.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I am him.

Speaker: lobsang
Dialogue: Not until you are eighteen.

Speaker: lobsang
Dialogue: Go study.  I get in trouble if you do not study.

Speaker: lobsang
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Sometimes you strike the goat, to scare the sheep.

Speaker: lobsang
Dialogue: I am the goat. He is a naughty sheep.

Speaker: father
Dialogue: He will not be ours much longer.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I have news.  The Regent has resigned his post.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Is he a bad man?  Norbu says he is "lavish" and "willful". "How can he give you monk's vows if he has not kept them himself?"

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Well, some say. It's not for you to worry about. Another will be chosen.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: He was always nice to me. He found me.  He saw me in his dreams.

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I turn you over again, today, Lhamo.  One day, you will not be able to come running to us.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: But you will always be here?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Me?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: You will always!

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: I have one more piece of news.  A baby is coming.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Oh, Mama!  Who will it be?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: Oh, no!  Who can it be?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: My teeth!  My teeth are in here!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: My old teeth!

Dialogue: "I take refuge in the three jewels, The Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangra."

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: You recite! You recite!

Dialogue: "I take refuge in the three jewels, The Buddha, the Dharma and the Sangra."

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: "Until I attain enlightenment."

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I would like you to be my new Regent.

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: The Four Noble Truths.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: The Four Noble Truths, as taught by the Lord Sakyamuni Buddha are: The Truth of Suffering The Truth of the Cause of Suffering, The Truth of the Cessation of Suffering, the Truth of the Way which leads to the cessation of Suffering.

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: I accept it. What is suffering?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: True suffering arises from contaminated actions and afflictions.  Birth, illness, grief, old age, poverty, pain, death - these are surferings.

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: I accept it. What are the causes of suffering?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: The causes of suffering arise from true sources.  Attachment, desire, envy, hatred, greed, unkindness, wrong view and so forth - these are some causes of suffering.

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: How does one progress from the realization of one Noble Truth to another?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: We will have to think about that.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I need to squeeze this brain.

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: Answer.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: When one understands that he causes some of his own suffering, needlessly, then he looks for the causes in his own life.

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: I accept it.

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: Careful!  Careful!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I need to jump! I love to jump!

Speaker: oracle
Dialogue: Heed the warning of your predecessor. Or the war will end here.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Oh, nicely done, Norbu.  I will get you.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: May I listen to the news with you, Holiness?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Please.

Dialogue: How big is Tibet's army?

Dialogue: Roughly five thousand men.

Dialogue: Is that big?

Dialogue: No.  Not very big.

Dialogue: The Regent is adding men. And he bought rifles and ammunition from India. Mountain guns, too.

Dialogue: Will we be in this war?

Dialogue: No.  This war is almost over.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Will we ever be in war?

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: We have enemies.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: The Chinese.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: But, surely, we are safe in Tibet. We don't believe in killing.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: No, we don't.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: This is Britain.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Ahh.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Where is Poland?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Where is Pearl Harbor?

Dialogue: In the Pacific Ocean.  It is an island.  American territory.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Where is Alsace?

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: I do not know, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: This is Tibet. And this is China.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Ahh.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Certainly, we are safe in Tibet.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: We hope, Kundun.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What was the warning of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama?

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: He warned about the future of Tibet.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Tell me.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: When it is time.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Patience is the first of the Six Perfections.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: One day, we will get that automobile running.

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: "To be born in a time when the Buddha has appeared. To be born in a time when the Buddha has taught. To be born when the teaching of Buddha is alive."

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: "To be born where the dharma is practiced. To be born in a time when people have compassion for other people."

Speaker: questioner
Dialogue: How is human life precious?

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: As a result of previous karma, you have obtained this human life. By means of this rebirth, through work and study, you can attain all everlasting happiness. In the words of Shantideva: "With the boat of this precious life, You can cross the waters of Samsara. How rare to find this boat!" "Oh, ignorant one, do not fall asleep now!"

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Sera, Sera Monastery. Reting.  Under arrest.  The army is taking him right past Sera! Monastery!  Those crazy monks!  Have been threatening trouble. Reting tried to assassinate Taktra Rinpoche.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: It's the army, firing on Sera Monastery! Oh, no!  Oh, no!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Why is this?  What is happening? Tell me!

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Reting Rinpoche has been arrested.  He tried to overthrow Regent Taktra. Today, he is brought back to Lhasa by government officials. The monks at Sera Monastery have been on his side.  Now, there is trouble between them and the army.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: I am sorry for you to have to witness this, Kundun.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Look here!

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Tragic.  Unnecessary.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Holiness? I have a letter.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: The Thirteenth Dalai Lama's warning. He wrote to you, the year before he died.  The year before you were born.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: "It may happen, that here in Tibet, religion and government will be attacked both from without and within. Unless we guard our own country..."

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: "...it will now happen that the Dalai and Panchen Lamas, the Father and the Son, and all the revered holders of the faith, will disappear and become nameless."

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: "Monks and their monasteries will be destroyed. The rule of law will be weakened. The lands and properties will be seized.  They themselves will be forced to serve their enemies or wander the country like beggars."

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What can I do?  I am only a boy.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: You are the man who wrote this letter.  You are the man who has come back to lead us.   You will soon have great responsibilities.  You must know what to do.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: You remember who you are. You called for them.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Taktra Rinpoche, I understand there was an attempt on your life.

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: It is possible, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: You are unharmed?

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: Completely.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Good.  Where is Reting Rinpoche now?

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: He has been imprisoned, here in the Potala, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: The Sera monks have surrendered?

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: It is calm.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Please, have tea.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I need to know what you know.  I am no longer a child.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Ask whatever you will.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What is the danger from the Chinese, now?

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: Very complicated, Holiness. Let me tell you current news.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Did you receive the letter?

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: We did not.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: The war is over. This is a time in when nations are redefining themselves.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: So, Tibet, too, needs to define itself.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Yes.  As a free country. But our attempts have proven futile.  We continue to be badly outmaneuvered by the Chinese.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Can India help us?

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: India is a newly independent nation.  They are struggling. India is in no position to help us.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Britain?

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Britain chooses not to.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: And, America?

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: America, we shall see.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Ask the Chinese mission to leave our country.  Immediately.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Quite simple.  Yes.  Good.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I shall send a letter to America, to the President, informing him of our problem.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I want Reting Rinpoche well cared for.  He is my teacher.  He found me.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Listen to this, Norbu. : To Mr Truman The President of the United States of America

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Reting Rinpoche has died in prison.

Speaker: layman
Dialogue: The Communist have control of China.

Speaker: layman
Dialogue: Now, as his great army, stands idle on our borders, Chairman Mao has presented Tibet with three demands:

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: We can concede that Tibet is a part of China if we can guarantee that the Dalai Lama's name and authority will remain...

Speaker: layman
Dialogue: And do you believe that the Tibetan government will be allowed to continue to function as it is? Do you believe that our religion will be protected?

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Give the Dalai Lama his majority!

Speaker: monk
Dialogue: We have dealt with this Chinese obsession for hundreds of years. We can deal with it now.

Speaker: layman
Dialogue: These are not the Chinese we know. These are Communists.

Speaker: voices
Dialogue: Make him Dalai Lama now!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: If we agree that we are part of China, nothing else will matter. Not trade, not defense. We will be lost.

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: What would you do, Holiness?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What should I do about my doubt, Teacher?

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: It is a difficult situation.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I mean, my doubt.  Why me? Am I Him?

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: Doubt is an affliction.  Reliquish it.  Accept.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I believe we must make no concesions to the Chinese.  But, I am one voice. The Dalai Lama has always trusted in the forces of Buddha.  Let us consult the protective deities.

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: We should not accept any conditions from the Chinese.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Enter.

Speaker: regent taktra
Dialogue: Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: regent taktra
Dialogue: The Chinese have invaded.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: They crossed the river, Holiness. They have invaded in six locations, Chando Province, Kham, eastern Tibet.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What is the size of our army, now?

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Eight thousand, five hundred, soldiers and officers. We have recently requested mortars, anti-aircraft guns and ammunition from India.  We have several hundred in the area.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Has anyone died?

Speaker: lord chmberlain
Dialogue: The radio contact said one officer had died.  Then he said, "The Chinese soldiers - they are coming." And then, the radio went dead.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: One man.  A man has died. One man is too many.

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: "This week, the People's Liberation Army crossed the Drichu River east of Chamdo and began the peaceful liberation of Tibet.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What do the people say, Norbu?

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Tibetan officials have retreated from Chamdo.  They are scared and running.  The Chinese strategy has destroyed the heart of our defense forces.  Chamdo falls, several other villages are lost.  You know what happens.  The road to Lhasa will be wide open.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: The people want you made Dalai Lama.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Then, I am lucky. I am still too young.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: These are dangerous times. They want the Dalai Lama to lead them.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: But, I have no experience.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Oh, but you do, Kundun. Who else would be here?

Speaker: oracle
Dialogue: "His time has come."

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: "To the members of the United Nations:

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: "Tibetans have for long lived a cloistered life in their mountain fastness, remote and aloof..."

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: I was never alone.  Two Chinese were with me every minute of the day.

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: Their talk is always of liberation and helpfulness.  They put their words like honey on a knife, but if you lick the honey, you will bleed.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Tell me.

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: They think they have convinced me. They think I am on their side. They have allowed me to leave Kumbum and come to Lhasa believing that I will try to turn you to their ways. If I do not succeed, I am to eliminate you.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: You, kill me?

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: Eliminate you.

Speaker: tarster rinpoche
Dialogue: I can be Governor of Lhasa, they say.

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: Don't eat all those sweets. You'll get sick.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Do you remember the day I came to your monastery, when I was a baby? And you comforted me?

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: I do.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I remember, too, actually. I was frightened then. I am frightened now.

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: The Chinese have one goal.  The complete dissolution of our nation. The destruction of our culture. There is no room for Buddha in their world.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: We cannot.

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: This is not a fight to put bread just in one's own mouth. This is a fight for Tibet.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Buddha teaches that we must learn from our enemy.  We have compassion for all people.

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: These are not human beings. They are worse than ghosts.

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: You are in great danger. The Dalai Lama cannot fall into Chinese hands. You must flee.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: How could I ever leave?

Speaker: takster rinpoche
Dialogue: It may not be your decision to make.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I accept it.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: We have telegraphed our appeal to the United Nations and await its reply. I am sending a delegation to China to negotiate the Chinese withdrawal.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: It seems that I must depart Lhasa. The majority wills it. Lukhangwa and Lobsang Tashi?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I am making you my Prime Ministers. You will stay here. You must always keep me informed, no matter how bad the news. I want plain information.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Today, I declare a general amnesty.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: You will not come?

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: No, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Am I running away?

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: The people will cry when they learn you are gone. But they would all want you safe.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Let me take this.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: You must study very hard, do not neglect the holy things during this time.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I will miss you.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: We have had fun, you and I. Fun for a little boy in an old palace.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: We have.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: You have grown up very good.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: And you have grown older and your chin has grown balder.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: Tonight, Kundun, you see the world. You place your feet on the shepherd boy's path.

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: "The Gods will be avenged."

Speaker: norbu thundrup
Dialogue: I will send it to you. It will work.

Speaker: bodyguard
Dialogue: We must go, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: A moment.

Speaker: bodyguard
Dialogue: Please, come, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Yes.  I am ready.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Safe journey.  Safe return.

Speaker: monks
Dialogue: Do not let him go! We beg of you, do not take him from us!

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: He goes for a short time, until the danger can be determined.  He will not leave Tibet.  He will return.

Speaker: ling rinpoche
Dialogue: He will return. The Precious One will not abandon you.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: All quiet?

Speaker: bodyguard
Dialogue: Yes, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Where are you from?

Speaker: bodyguard
Dialogue: Kham, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Your people are very brave. They are fighting the Chinese. No one can stop them. Not even me.

Speaker: bodyguard
Dialogue: Khambas are wild men.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I worry about them.

Speaker: bodyguard
Dialogue: Do not worry, Holiness. They fight for you. They are under your protection.

Speaker: bodyguard
Dialogue: Holiness, this has come for you.

Speaker: muslim man
Dialogue: Eighteen children.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Eighteen, wonderful.

Speaker: muslim man
Dialogue: And not a monk among them.

Speaker: muslim man
Dialogue: No, no son of mine will sit and read books and eat up the poor people's butter while my people have to butcher the cows and sheep because these holy men can't kill an animal.  They can eat it, can't they?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Did you love your husband, before you married?

Speaker: tibetan woman
Dialogue: I did not know him before I married him.  I loved his brother, but then, I married his brother, too.  He is dead now.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Hmm.

Speaker: tibetan woman
Dialogue: The land has stayed in the family. We work together.  The nobleman is not too bad.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Does he treat you fairly?

Speaker: tibetan woman
Dialogue: Not too bad.  Rich is rich, poor is poor.  We are different. Are you married?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: tibetan woman
Dialogue: Too young?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Much too young.

Speaker: tibetan woman
Dialogue: Look for a strong woman, not too occupied with her beauty. Look for a woinan who keeps her hands busy.  Look for a kind heart.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Like my mother.

Speaker: tibetan woman
Dialogue: I see that.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: This little brother was terribly sweet.  When he died, my mother was so sad.  A lama said to her, before the little brother was laid out for burial, take a bit of butter and rub a spot on his skin.  He will come back to you, you will see. So, my mother did this, and a few years later, a new boy was born.

Speaker: noble boy
Dialogue: Does he have the spot?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: He does, a little spot where the butter had been.

Speaker: noble boy
Dialogue: Is that a true story, or pretend?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What do you think?

Speaker: noble boy
Dialogue: True.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: You decide.

Speaker: noble boy
Dialogue: What does the butter spot feel like?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Soft.  Nice. I have a good friend back in Lhasa.  He has a very poor beard, with a little spot on his chin where no hair grows.  It feels like that.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: Of the Tibetan delegations sent abroad, all have been turned away.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: Britain, Nepal, America, India. All of those governments have refused to meet with our representatives.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: And the United Nations?  Surely?

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: The United Nations voted not to hear our appeal.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: One country did sponsor the resolution.  A land called "El Salvador".

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Where is that?

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: In the Americas.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: So, we must face China and all her might alone.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: Yes. Most of the Chamdo region is now in Chinese hands.  There is a report from Chamdo which makes quite clear that, unless some settlement can soon be reached, Communist troops will soon be marching on Lhasa.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: With much bloodshed.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: I am afraid.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I want at all costs to avoid this. Do we have news from the delegation in China?

Speaker: kashag memberr
Dialogue: Not yet, but the Governor of Chamdo, Ngabo Jigme, suggests we must negotiate and offers to go to Peking.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: He is a capable man.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Your prime minsters would argue that such negotiations should take place in Lhasa.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: And then they would concede that the times are desperate and we must go to Peking.  Agreed.  Send Ngabo.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Time to study.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Wait.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: We are in the last outposts of Tibet. Let's do away with some of this formality.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: He is a modern man. Just like he was the last time.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: "I will liberate those not liberated." I will release those not released. I will relieve those not relieved. May I deliver them to the state of enlightenment."

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: Ngabo did not have the state seal.  He could not sign.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Yes, but they say he did.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: Holiness?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: General Chiang Chin-wu, the Chinese representative, is en route to Dromo. He is coming to meet you.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Then, we shall meet.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: General Chiang.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Thank you.  Please sit.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I have.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Soon.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Let me see the agreement.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Counterfeit.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I thought he would be some kind of monster, even with horns growing out of his head.  But, he is only a man, just an ordinary human being, like myself.  Life is always a lesson.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: Your Prime Ministers, support the proposal that you return to Lhasa. On the opposite hand, some officials urge you not to return.  They believe you should leave now, for India.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: If I were to go into exile, could we expect any serious assistance, from India, suppose?

Speaker: lord chanberlain
Dialogue: It is unlikely.  America, perhaps. There is great anti-communist feeling in America.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: At this point, the most likely result of a foreign pact is war.

Speaker: lord chaaberlain
Dialogue: The Chinese would see such a pact as an open declaration of war.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Tibet, at war?  No. China is close, America is far away.  After countless people die, China would still, always, be close.  We will work with what we have.

Speaker: kashag member
Dialogue: And as for your own safety, Holiness?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I am scared.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Shall we consult the protective deities, Holiness?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: My first and foremost duty is to protect my people.  I feel sure of this.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Impermanence. Our own short lifetimes are not the only valid consideration.

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: I hope you will not feel badly about all the things of childhood you missed.

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: You lost so much.  I am sorry.

Speaker: taktra rinpoche
Dialogue: Goodbye, Kundun.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: No!

Speaker: father
Dialogue: Goodbye, Kundun.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: No, Norbu!

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: I am not a foreigner! I refuse to be treated like one.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: You see here thangkas of the Fifth Dalai Lama, the founder of our government.  It is tradition at formal meetings for these thangkas to be hung.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: Superstitions.  Tibet is part of a modern nation.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: I want the songs stopped.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Songs?  What songs?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I have no authority to ban singing in my country.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: You must also do something about the public meetings.  I see this, memorandum circulating, with Tibetan grievances.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: You have cracked a man's skull and that crack has not healed. It is too soon to expect him to be your friend.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: We are simply respecting the terms of the Seventeen Point Agreement.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: Are you, General?

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: We want 2,000 more tons of barley distributed.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: Impossible!  You will bring famine down on the people of Tibet with these insatiable demands! More food, the best land for your soldiers to camp.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: The People's Liberation Army pays for all food and lodging.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: So far, they do. But, the quantity, it does not exist.  You will have to re- evaluate your needs.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: How much tea do you drink, Prime Minister?

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: It depends on the quality. And, that it be Indian.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: Why is it necessary for the Chinese to keep so many soldiers in Lhasa?

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: To protect.  To serve you. Chairman Mao wants you to feel that China belongs to you now.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: Chairman Mao can keep China. Just give us back Tibet.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: Plans for absorbing the Tibetan army into the People's Army will soon be finalized.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: I will not approve it.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: Then, we will begin with replacing the Tibetan flag with the flag of the Motherland.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: And we will begin with tearing it down.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I am so sorry.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: It must be done. We can no longer meet with the Chinese, they refuse us.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I accept your resignations.

Speaker: lobsang tashi
Dialogue: Have you chosen your new Prime Ministers, Holiness?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: There will be no new Prime Ministers.

Speaker: lukhangwa
Dialogue: You will face great difficulties, Holiness.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: They have taken away our silence.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I have great hopes for the future of our co-operation.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I am happy to hear you say this, Chairman Mao.  I have created a reform committee to investigate grievances and we have abolished Inherited Tax, and forgiven all money owed the Government by people who are unable to pay.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: For me, I think such a mix is crucial.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: "If moral discipline is learned from the beginning, one possesses the root for achieving higher rebirth.  A staircase for achieving liberation.  An antidote eliminating misery and sorrow.  Without discipline there is no method."

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I am thinking of becoming a Communist Party Member. I like what I see of Marxism.  It is based on equality and justice for all. I believe Chairman Mao wishes the best for our people.  Our path must be non-violence.  Co-operation.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I leave tomorrow.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I have been greatly impressed by your accomplishments.  Industrial progress.  Great efficiency. Your people are capable and courteous.

Speaker: dalai lama
Dialogue: Always.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: He will betray us.

Speaker: lord chambepiain
Dialogue: Did you ever doubt it?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I had relinquished doubt.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Are you happy?

Speaker: old woman
Dialogue: I am very happy and prosperous under the guidance of the Chinese Communist Party and chairman Mao Tse Tung.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I ask them to stop, to lay down their guns.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: The Khamba's gun is his most prized possession.  I admire them so. They face a modern, well equipped army, and still, they fight.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Land reform is underway in Amdo.  The large estates are being confiscated and redistributed. Landlords are being punished.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: A beggar can be called a landlord if he disapproves of the Chinese.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I have always asked for plain information.  Just the truth.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: The Communists put their guns in the hands of the Khamba children and force the child to kill the parent. They have dropped bombs on the monastery of Lithang in Kham.  It has been destroyed. Women and children, trying to escape from the fighting, have been shot with machine guns, fired from airplanes.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: The pursuit of non-violence. Very difficult.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: Non-violence means co-operation when it is possible.  Resistance, when it is not.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: We have decided that no drastic changes will take place in Tibet for six years. This should make you happy.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: It seems a revolt has broken out in the east. We have decided that the Tibetan army must be used against the Khamba guerrillas.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I will not approve it.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: You have bombed on peaceful people.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: We must deal with these reactionaries!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: No.  We are peace loving people. I am afraid we cannot trust you.

Speaker: general chiang
Dialogue: We are here to heal the people of Tibet.  You need reform. You have no sense of what is good for your people. We are here to liberate you!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I burn here, but I am not suppose to let the smoke show.  Yes, we need reform.  The monasteries. Communications.  Schools.  But we want change for Tibet, as Tibet needs it, not for China.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Buddha is our physician, General, he will heal us.  Comapssion and enlightnement will set us free. You can not liberate me I can only liberate myself.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: They will take Lhasa next.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: The people will not allow it.

Speaker: nechung oracle
Dialogue: Where there is no crossing a big river, no fords, no shallows, where the only hope is a boat, and there is no boat... I will put a boat, Kundun.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: AND OTHERS  "With folded hands I beseech the Buddhas of all directions. To shine the lamp of Dharma For all bewildered in the gloom of misery."

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: The crowd will not disperse until you give your assurance that you will not attend the Chinese festivities. Many who have been invited to dine with the Chinese do not return home.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I will not go.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: I will alert the Chinese delegation.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Do you think I must?

Speaker: mother
Dialogue: You decide.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Tibet has never been part of China.  We are different races. We are different cultures. We need change, we know that. But we could do it alone. We were just about to do it alone.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I am afraid I will go. Far, far away.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: We are now accused of aiding the rebels.  The Chinese said we can expect drastic measures to be taken to crush this revolt.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Arrange for me to speak to the people's leaders.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I fear that there will be great bloodshed if you cannot convince the people to disperse and go home. I am safe.

Speaker: first leader
Dialogue: Holiness, the Chinese tried to entice you to their garrison with out protection of bodyguard. Even now, they urge you to come to them for safety. They are bringing more troops and guns and artillery into Lhasa. There are three airplanes waiting outside Lhasa. What do they wait for?  They are planning to kill the Dalai Lama.  Don't you see?

Speaker: nechung oracle
Dialogue: Stay.

Speaker: nechung oracle
Dialogue: Stay.  I tell you to stay.

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: The Chinese are planning to attack the crowd and shell the Norbulinka. You are asked to indicate on a map where you will be so that the artillery men will not mistakenly aim at you.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Tell them I will be here. With my people. Right here.

Speaker: oracle
Dialogue: Go!  Go!  Tonight!

Speaker: oracle
Dialogue: Go!  Tonight!  Go!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Dim the lights.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Wait.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I see a safe journey.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I see a safe return.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: Now.  I am ready.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Move aside, tour of inspection, move aside.

Speaker: khamba bodyguard
Dialogue: Move aside, let us through. Move aside!

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I have always loved mountains.

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: "Right will be victorious."

Speaker: lord chamberlain
Dialogue: "The Gods will be avenged!"

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I repudiate the Seventeen Point Agreement

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I constitute the Government of Tibet, the only legal authority in the land.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: With all respect, may I ask? Who are you?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: What you see before you is a man.  A simple monk.

Speaker: soldier
Dialogue: Are you the Lord Buddha?

Speaker: tenzin gyatso
Dialogue: I think I am a reflection, like the moon, on water. When you see me, and I try to be a good man, see yourself
